cc:Work.dc:title: Plato's Divided Line
cc:Work.dc:description: A geometrical and dynamically annotated visual representation of the discussion of the divided line in Plato's "Republic" at 509d-511e.

path.desc: Short horizontal line for point E on the line
path.title: Marker E

use.desc: Short horizontal line for endpoint A on the line
use.title: Marker A

use.desc: Short horizontal line for point C on the line
use.title: Marker C

use.desc: Short horizontal line for point D on the line
use.title: Marker D

use.desc: Short horizontal line for endpoint B on the line
use.title: Marker B

text.title: Capital Letter A
text.tspan: A

text.title: Capital Letter E
text.tspan: E

text.title: Capital Letter C
text.tspan: C

text.title: Capital Letter D
text.tspan: D

text.title: Capital Letter B
text.tspan: B

text.desc: The simile or analogy (or whatever it is) of the divided line in Plato's "Republic" dialogue at Stephanus numbers 509d to 511e, just before Book 7.
text.title: Plato's Divided Line
text.tspan: Plato's Divided Line

text.desc: The passage is from Plato's "Republic" starting at 509d. The translation is G. M. A. Grube's, as revised by C. D. C. Reeve, from Hackett Publishing Company.
text.title: Attribution
text.tspan: (Republic 509d - 511e)

text.desc: The text of the "Republic" at 509e and going to 511e, with some omissions (notably the bit about geometry). The translation is Grube's, as revised by Reeve.
text.title: Plato's text at 509d to 511e of the Republic with Socrates and Glaucon the speakers
text.tspan: It is like a line divided into two unequal sections. Then divide each section—namely, that of the visible
and that of the intelligible—in the same ratio as the line. In terms now of relative clarity and opacity, one
subsection of the visible consists of images. And by images I mean, first, shadows, then reflections in
water and in all close-packed, smooth, and shiny materials, and everything of that sort, if you understand.
I do. [510a]
In the other subsection of the visible, put the originals of these images, namely, the animals around us,
all the plants, and the whole class of manufactured things.
Consider them put.
Would you be willing to say that, as regards truth and untruth, the division is in this proportion: As the
opinable is to the knowable, so the likeness is to the thing that it is like?
Certainly. [510b]
Consider now how the section of the intelligible is to be divided.
How?
As follows: In one subsection, the soul, using as images the things that were imitated before, is forced
to investigate from hypotheses, proceeding not to a first principle but to a conclusion. In the other
subsection, however, it makes its way to a first principle that is not a hypothesis, proceeding from a
hypothesis but without the images used in the previous subsection, using forms themselves and making
its investigation through them.
. . . [the bit about geometry: 510c - 511a] . . .
Then also understand that, by the other subsection of the intelligible, I mean that which reason itself
grasps by the power of dialectic. It does not consider these hypotheses as first principles but truly as
hypotheses—but as stepping stones to take off from, enabling it to reach the unhypothetical first
principle of everything. Having grasped this principle, it reverses itself and, keeping hold of what
follows from it, comes down to a conclusion without making use of anything visible at all, but only
of forms themselves, moving on from forms to forms, and ending in forms.
. . . [Glaucon's summary: 511c - 511d] . . .
Thus there are four such conditions in the soul, corresponding to the four subsections of our line:
Understanding for the highest, thought for the second, belief for the third, and imaging for the last.
Arrange them in a ratio, and consider that each shares in clarity to the degree that the subsection it is
set over shares in truth.

path.desc: Line segment AE, at the top and longest. This AE segment in the intelligible section of the line represents dialectical reasoning, culminating in understanding and knowledge of the forms such as square itself, beauty itself, or justice itself.
path.title: Vertical Line AE

path.desc: Line segment EC, immediately below AE, sort of in the middle of the line. This EC segment of the lower intelligible section of the line represents thinking with the aid of images of intelligible objects (such as numbers and idealized geometrical figures).
path.title: Vertical Line EC

path.desc: Line segment CD, below EC (and equal in length to EC even though Plato does not explicitly mention this), about three- fourths of the way down the line. This CD segment in the visible section represents beliefs regarding the originals (such as animals, plants, and human artifacts) which are the source of the images in DB.
path.title: Vertical Line CD

path.desc: Line segment DB, the last (or lowest) and shortest of the segments. This DB segment of the lower visible section represents images such as shadows and reflections on which mere opinion and conjecture are based.
path.title: Vertical Line DB

rect.desc: The divided line is an analogy in Plato's Republic dialogue. The analogy is between the ratios of the various sections of the line and the relations between levels of reality and our knowledge of what exists at those various levels.
rect.title: Plato's Divided Line

text.tspan: The divided line is an analogy in Plato's Republic dialogue. It occurs from
509d to 511e at the end of Book Six (out of a total of ten books). The
middle books of the Republic are heavy into metaphysics (the study of
the nature of being or existing in general) and epistemology (the study of
the nature and limits of knowledge), and the divided line seems to have
something to say about these areas of philosophical interest. In particular,
the analogy appears (the correct interpretation a matter of dispute) to be
between the ratios of the various sections of the line and the relations
between levels of reality and of our knowledge of what exists at those
various levels. In general, the things that exist at the lower levels, things
such as images and physical objects, are less real, being only imperfect
copies of the purely intelligible things existing at the higher levels; and it
is only of these latter that we have true understanding, knowing them only
through our mind rather than through our easily corruptible senses.
Line segment AE, at the top and longest. This
upper subsection of the intelligible section of the
line represents dialectical reasoning, culminating
in understanding and knowledge of the forms
such as square itself, beauty itself, or justice itself.
Line segment EC, immediately below AE,
sort of in the middle of the line. This sub-
section of the lower intelligible section of
the line represents thinking with the aid of
images of intelligible objects (such as
numbers and geometrical figures).
Line segment CD, below EC (and equal in
length to EC even though Plato does not
explicitly mention this), about three-fourths
of the way down the line. This upper subsection
of the visible section represents beliefs
regarding the originals (such as animals, plants,
and human artifacts) which are the source of
the images in line segment DB.
Line segment DB, the last (or lowest) and
shortest of the segments. This lowest subsection
of the visible section represents images such as
shadows and reflections which provide material
for the imagination.
Line AB is properly vertical
because the line also represents
a scale of higher and lower being
or ways of existing. What exists
at the lower end, toward endpoint
B, is less perfect, less good, less
real, than what exists toward the
other end of the line at endpoint A.
This talk of being or existing is a
metaphysical interpretation of the
meaning of the divided line. There is
also an epistemological interpretation
according to which the different
segments of the line correspond,
not to different ways of existing,
but to different cognitive or mental
states such as believing or knowing.

rect.desc: Line segment AC is one section, representing the intelligible, and line segment CB, representing the visible, is another section.
rect.title: Two Unequal Sections: AC and CB

text.tspan: Line segment AC, representing the intelligible, is
larger than line segment CB, representing the visible.
Why this inequality? One possibility is that there are
more things existing in the intelligible world than in
the visible world. For example, numbers are abstract
entities that exist in the intelligible world, and there
are an infinite number of them. Another example:
geometrical figures such as polygons are infinite in
number, for there is a polygon corresponding to each
number that exists. Even though we cannot draw these
many-many-sided figures in the visible world, they
exist as objects of thought in the intelligible world.
Another possible explanation for the inequality of the
sections is that Plato holds that the kind of being
possessed by the existences in the intelligible world is
in some sense better than the kind of being possessed
by those things existing in the visible world. On this
second explanation, the inequality of the sections is
due to qualitative rather than quantitative differences.

rect.desc: Line segment CB, at the lower end of the line, is the visible section.
rect.title: Visible: CB

text.tspan: visible

rect.desc: Line segment AC is the longer, upper section of the line and represents the intelligible.
rect.title: Intelligible: AC

text.tspan: intelligible

rect.desc: AC is to CB as AE is to EC as CD is to DB.
rect.title: Same Ratio

text.tspan: Ratio AC:CB is the same as
ratio AE:EC which is the same as
ratio CD:DB.
A
C
B
A
E
C
C
D
B
The significance of these ratios
seems to be this: the variation in
truth and reality between AC and
CB is the same as the variation to
be found between CD and DB,
and likewise between the other
proportional ratios.

rect.desc: Clarity and Opacity increase from B to A
rect.title: Clarity and Opacity

text.tspan: Direction of
increasing
clarity and
opacity

rect.desc: DB is the lower subsection of the visible and consists of images.
rect.title: DB Subsection of the Visible

text.tspan: Line segment DB, lower subsection of the
visible section, contains images such as
shadows and reflections. These images are
imperfect copies or imitations of the things
that exist in the next higher subsection,
CD, of the visible section.

rect.desc: Line segment CD is the upper subsection of the visible and contains the original objects the images of which exist in the lower subsection DB.
rect.title: Other Subsection of the Visible

text.tspan: Line segment CD is the upper subsection
of the visible and contains the original
objects the images of which exist in the
lowest subsection, DB, of the visible
section. These originals are visible things
such as animals, plants, and objects
constructed by humans.

rect.desc: Things in DB are like the things in CD, as opinion is to knowledge as regards truth and falsity.
rect.title: Likeness

text.tspan: Socrates says the images in DB are like the
originals in CD, similar to the way in which
opinion is related to knowledge as far as truth
and untruth are concerned. The suggestion
seems to be that in moving from images to
originals we get closer to knowledge and truth.

rect.desc: In the lower subsection, EC, of the intelligible, the mind uses images of the original things in CD and hypotheses to arrive at conclusions.
rect.title: One Subsection of the Intelligible

text.tspan: In the lower subsection, EC, of the intelligible section, the mind uses as images the original
things in CD and starts from hypotheses to arrive at conclusions. Socrates gives the example
of geometrical figures to make clear what exactly the mind is using as images in this sub-
section. The mind is using the originals in CD as images; that is, for instance, the triangle we
draw on a sheet of paper or that a teacher draws on a chalkboard is a visible thing and is thus
an original in CD, and from that drawn triangle the mind constructs an idealized mental
image of a triangle; it is this idealized mental image that the mind uses in subsection EC.
Socrates also uses mathematical thinking as his example of the kind of thought processes
going on in the mind as it works from the hypotheses to the conclusions.

g.desc: Line segment AE is the upper subsection of the intelligible.
g.title: Other Subsection of the Intelligible

text.tspan: In subsection AE of the intelligible section of the line, the mind no longer uses images; it uses
the forms themselves (such as the good itself, beauty itself, equality itself, etc.) to reason from
hypotheses to a first principle. The rational mind reaches this first principle by drawing on the
power of dialectic. The mind would use this power, for instance, to progress first from the
idealized mental image of a triangle used by the geometer in subsection EC, then to progress to
the abstract mathematical conception of a triangle, and then, finally, entering subsection AE,
to progress to the philosopher's direct acquaintance with the eternal, unchanging, intelligible
form of triangleness. Now having knowledge and understanding of the first principle, the mind,
still using only forms,
goes back down (the
line, so to speak),
drawing now correct
conclusions along the
way, fixing prior
opinions and beliefs.

rect.desc: Dialectic is a method of argumentation by which the forms can became known.
rect.title: Dialectic

text.tspan: The mind or soul uses its power to reason dialectically in order to come to
know and understand the intelligible forms such as goodness itself and
beauty itself and equality itself. Plato never makes it entirely clear what
exactly dialectic is. It seems, however, to be a kind of method or technique
of argumentation that especially uses questions and answers, and definitions
and distinctions, in order to refute incorrect views, and thereby progress
toward correct views. Those trained in the technique can acquire knowledge
of first principles from which non-hypothetical conclusions can be drawn.
Dialectic is used only in this subsection of the intelligible section because
in dialectic there is direct apprehension of the forms and the forms only
exist in this subsection.

g.desc: Each subsection of the line corresponds to a different mental or cognitive state: understanding with AE; thought with EC; belief with CD; and imaging with DB.
g.title: Four Condition in the Soul

text.tspan: Each subsection of the line corresponds
to a different mental or cognitive state:
understanding with AE;
thinking with EC;
believing with CD;
imaging with DB.
The ratios of the subsections with respect
to each other are supposed to tell us how
these various states compare with regard
to clarity and truth.
Understanding (noesis)
Knowing
Dialectical Reasoning
Thinking (dianoia)
Mathematical Reasoning
Believing (pistis)
Opining
Imaging (eikasia)
Conjuring
